*   It is permitted to play the ball high above the attacking circle so it lands outside, as long as it's not dangerous and not legitimately playable by another player during its flight. **(rule 13.2)**
*   The ball may be raised immediately using a push, flick, or scoop, but not intentionally using a hit. **(rule 13.2)**

*   When the ball travels over the side-line, play is re-started not more than one metre from where the ball crossed the side-line. **(rule 7.3a)**

details.question: In indoor field hockey, according to the Rules, what is awarded when a player or team is disadvantaged by an opponent breaking the Rules?

details.bot_answer:
When an opponent breaks the rules and causes a disadvantage to a player or team, a penalty is awarded.

*   A penalty is awarded when a player or team has been disadvantaged by an opponent breaking the Rules. **(rule 12.1)**
*   A penalty stroke is awarded for an offense by a defender in the circle that prevents the probable scoring of a goal. **(rule 12.4)**
*   A penalty stroke is awarded for an intentional offense in the circle by a defender against an opponent who has possession of the ball. **(rule 12.4)**
*   A penalty corner is awarded for an offense by a defender in the circle that does not prevent the probable scoring of a goal. **(rule 12.3)**
*   A penalty corner is awarded for an intentional offense in the circle by a defender against an opponent who does not have possession of the ball or an opportunity to play the ball. **(rule 12.3)**
*   A penalty corner is awarded for an intentional offense by a defender outside the circle but within the half of the pitch they are defending. **(rule 12.3)**
*   A penalty corner is awarded for intentionally playing the ball over the back-line by a defender. **(rule 12.3)**
*   A penalty corner is awarded against a team that carried out a substitution incorrectly. **(rule 12.3)**
*   A penalty corner is awarded when the ball becomes lodged in a player's clothing or equipment while in the circle they are defending. **(rule 12.3)**
*   Playing the ball deliberately and hard into an opponent's stick, feet or hands with associated risk of injury when a player is in a 'set' or stationary position is considered dangerous play. **(rule 9.8)**
*   Players collecting, turning and trying to play the ball deliberately through a defending player who is either close to the player in possession or is trying to play the ball are considered dangerous actions. **(rule 9.8)**
*   A personal penalty may be awarded in addition to the appropriate penalty for dangerous play. **(rule 9.8)**
*   For any offense, the offending player may be cautioned (green card), temporarily suspended for 1 minute (green card), temporarily suspended for a minimum of 2 minutes (yellow card), or permanently suspended (red card). **(rule 14.1)**
*   For each temporary or permanent suspension, the offending team plays with one fewer player. **(rule 14.1)**
*   A team must not have more than six players on the pitch at any particular time. **(rule 2.1)**
*   If a team has more than the permitted number of players on the pitch, time should be stopped to correct the situation. **(rule 2.1)**
*   A personal penalty may be awarded against the captain of the team involved for an accidental breach of the player number rule. **(rule 2.1)**
*   For a serious breach of the player number rule, a personal penalty must be awarded. **(rule 2.1)**
*   If the ball hits any discarded equipment, such as a hand protector, knee pads or a face mask, outside the circle, a free push is awarded. **(rule 9.17)**
*   If the ball hits any discarded equipment, such as a hand protector, knee pads or a face mask, inside the circle, a penalty corner is awarded. **(rule 9.17)**
*   If the ball hits any discarded equipment, such as a hand protector, knee pads or a face mask, and this prevents a certain goal from being scored, a penalty stroke is awarded. **(rule 9.17)**
*   If the stroke is taken before the whistle is blown and a goal is not scored, a free push is awarded to the defence. **(rule 13.9)**
*   For any other offense by the player taking the stroke, a free push is awarded to the defence. **(rule 13.9)**
*   For any offense by the player defending the stroke, including moving either foot before the ball has been played, the penalty stroke is taken again. **(rule 13.9)**
*   If the player defending the stroke prevents a goal being scored but moves either foot before the ball has been played, this player may be cautioned and for any subsequent offense must be suspended. **(rule 13.9)**
*   If a goal is scored even though there has been an offense by the player defending the stroke, the goal is awarded. **(rule 13.9)**
*   For an offense by a player of the defending team and a goal is not scored, the penalty stroke is taken again. **(rule 13.9)**
*   For an offense by a player of the attacking team other than the player taking the stroke and a goal is scored, the penalty stroke is taken again. **(rule 13.9)**
*   A free push is awarded to the defending team if a penalty corner is not awarded and the ball travels over a side-board. **(rule 13.5)**
*   A free push is awarded to the defending team if a penalty corner is not awarded and the ball travels more than 3 metres outside the circle. **(rule 13.5)**
*   A free push is awarded to the defending team if a penalty corner is not awarded and the ball is played over the back-line. **(rule 13.5)**
*   A free push is awarded to the defending team if a defender commits an offense which does not result in another penalty corner. **(rule 13.5)**
*   Umpires must apply the advantage Rule as much as possible to assist a flowing and open match but without losing control. **(rule 1.4)**
details.reasoning: The student's answer correctly identifies that a 'penalty' is awarded when a player or team is disadvantaged by an opponent breaking the rules. This aligns with the ground truth answer.

details.question: According to the rules, what action are players prohibited from performing with the ball in indoor hockey?
details.ground_truth: Players must not hit the ball.
details.bot_answer:
Players are prohibited from performing several actions with the ball in indoor hockey, including playing it with the back of their stick, using any part of their stick above shoulder height (with exceptions for defenders saving shots), trapping or holding the ball against the sideboards, and playing the ball dangerously. Additionally, field players are not allowed to intentionally use any part of their body to stop, kick, propel, pick up, throw, or carry the ball, though accidental contact may not always be an offense if no advantage is gained.

*   Players must not play the ball with the back of the stick. **(rule 9.6)**
*   Players must not play the ball with any part of the stick when the ball is above shoulder height, with the exception that defenders may use their stick to stop or deflect a shot at goal at any height. **(rule 9.7)**
*   Players must not trap or hold the ball against the sideboards. **(rule 9.19)**
*   Players must not trap the ball against the sideboards by opponents with their sticks flat on the floor; opponents must leave a reasonable outlet. **(rule 9.19)**
*   Umpires should interrupt play with a bully re-start when the ball is trapped between players' sticks or unintentionally trapped against the side-boards. **(rule 9.19)**
*   Repeated instances of players trapping or holding the ball against the side-boards should be viewed as an intentional offense and penalized accordingly. **(rule 9.19)**
*   Players who deliberately aim to trap the ball between their stick and an opponent's stick should be penalized. **(rule 9.19)**
*   Players must not play the ball dangerously or in a way that leads to dangerous play. **(rule 9.8)**
*   A ball is considered dangerous when it causes legitimate evasive action by opposition players. **(rule 9.8)**
*   Playing the ball deliberately and hard into an opponent's stick, feet, or hands with associated risk of injury when the opponent is in a 'set' or stationary position is a dangerous action. **(rule 9.8)**
*   Players collecting, turning, and trying to play the ball deliberately through a defending player who is close or trying to play the ball are dangerous actions. **(rule 9.8)**
*   Field players must not stop, kick, propel, pick up, throw, or carry the ball with any part of their body. **(rule 9.11)**
*   It is not always an offense if the ball hits the foot, hand, or body of a field player; an offense occurs if they gain an advantage or position themselves with the intention of stopping the ball. **(rule 9.11)**
*   It is not an offense if the ball touches the hand holding the stick but would otherwise have touched the stick. **(rule 9.11)**
*   Goalkeepers wearing full protective equipment are permitted to use their stick, feet, kickers, legs, or leg guards to propel or stop/deflect the ball within their defending circle. **(rule 10.2)**
*   Goalkeepers wearing full protective equipment are permitted to use their arms, hands, or any other part of their body to push the ball away, but only as part of a goal-saving action or to move the ball away from a scoring possibility. **(rule 10.2)**
*   Goalkeepers are not permitted to propel the ball forcefully with arms, hands, or body so that it travels a long distance. **(rule 10.2)**
*   Goalkeepers must not conduct themselves in a manner that is dangerous to other players by taking advantage of their protective equipment. **(rule 10.2)**
*   A defender who is clearly running into the shot or into the taker without attempting to play the ball with their stick during a penalty corner must be penalized for dangerous play. **(rule 13.3 j)**
details.reasoning: The student's answer lists several prohibited actions, but it fails to identify the most fundamental prohibition according to the ground truth: players must not hit the ball. The ground truth is a concise statement of a primary rule, and the student's answer, while factually correct about other rules, misses this core prohibition.

details.question: In indoor hockey, what specific situations at the end of each quarter and full-time necessitate prolonging the match?
details.ground_truth: The match is prolonged to allow completion of a penalty corner or any subsequent penalty corner or penalty stroke.
details.bot_answer:
The match is extended at the end of each quarter and at full-time to allow for the completion of a penalty corner or any subsequent penalty corner or penalty stroke. Umpires are responsible for ensuring the full time is played and for indicating the end of time, prolonging the quarter if necessary for a penalty corner.

*   The match is prolonged at the end of each quarter and full-time to allow completion of a penalty corner or any subsequent penalty corner or penalty stroke. **(rule 13.4)**
*   Umpires are responsible for ensuring that the full time is played and for indicating the end of time for each quarter and for the completion of a penalty corner if a quarter is prolonged. **(rule 11.5)**
*   If time expires just before an umpire would otherwise have made a decision, umpires are permitted to make that decision immediately after the end of any period of the match. **(page 20)**
*   A penalty corner is prolonged until one of the following occurs: a goal is scored, a free push is awarded to the defending team, the ball travels more than 3 metres outside the circle, the ball is played over the back-line and a penalty corner is not awarded, the ball travels over a side-board and a penalty corner is not awarded, a defender commits an offence which does not result in another penalty corner, or a penalty stroke is awarded. **(rule 13.5)**
details.reasoning: The student's answer accurately reflects the ground truth by stating that the match is prolonged to allow for the completion of a penalty corner or any subsequent penalty corner or penalty stroke. The additional information provided by the student regarding the umpire's responsibility and the conditions for prolonging a penalty corner, while not strictly required by the ground truth, does not detract from the core correctness of their answer.

details.question: In indoor hockey, a goalkeeper wearing full protective equipment is permitted to use their arms, hands, and any other part of their body to push the ball away under what specific circumstances, according to the provided text?
details.ground_truth: The action is permitted only as part of a goal-saving action or to move the ball away from the possibility of a goal-scoring action by opponents. It does not permit a goalkeeper to propel the ball forcefully with arms, hands, or body so that it travels a long distance.
details.bot_answer:
A goalkeeper wearing full protective equipment can use their arms, hands, and any other part of their body to push the ball away, but only as part of a goal-saving action or to move the ball away from a potential scoring opportunity. This action is not permitted to propel the ball forcefully over a long distance.

*   Goalkeepers wearing full protective equipment are permitted to use their arms, hands, and any other part of their body to push the ball away. **(rule 10.2 b)**
*   This action is permitted only as part of a goal-saving action or to move the ball away from the possibility of a goal-scoring action by opponents. **(rule 10.2 b)**
*   This rule does not permit a goalkeeper to propel the ball forcefully with arms, hands, or body so that it travels a long distance. **(rule 10.2 b)**
*   Goalkeepers wearing full protective equipment are permitted to use their stick, feet, kickers, legs, or leg guards to stop the ball or deflect it in any direction, including over the back-line, when the ball is inside the circle they are defending and they have their stick in their hand. **(rule 10.2 a)**
*   Goalkeepers are not permitted to conduct themselves in a manner which is dangerous to other players by taking advantage of the protective equipment they wear. **(rule 10.2)**
*   Goalkeepers must wear protective equipment comprising at least headgear, leg guards, and kickers. **(rule 4.4)**
*   Protective headgear must be worn by a goalkeeper at all times, except when taking a penalty stroke. **(rule 10.1)**
*   When the ball is outside the circle they are defending, goalkeepers are only permitted to play the ball with their stick. **(rule 10.4)**
*   A goalkeeper who wears protective equipment must not take part in the match outside the half of the pitch they are defending, except when taking a penalty stroke. **(rule 10.1)**
details.reasoning: The student's answer accurately captures all the key points from the ground truth answer. It correctly states that the action is permitted only as part of a goal-saving action or to move the ball away from a potential scoring opportunity, and that it does not permit propelling the ball forcefully over a long distance. The phrasing is slightly different but the meaning is identical.

details.question: In indoor hockey, where must a temporarily suspended player remain until the umpire allows them to resume play?
details.ground_truth: In a designated place.
details.bot_answer:
A temporarily suspended player must remain in a designated place until the umpire permits them to return to play. They are allowed to rejoin their team at quarter and half-time breaks, but must then return to their designated spot to complete their suspension.

*   Temporarily suspended players must stay in a designated location until the umpire permits them to resume play. **(rule 14.2)**
*   Temporarily suspended players can rejoin their team during quarter and half-time breaks. **(rule 14.3)**
*   After a quarter or half-time break, temporarily suspended players must return to a designated place to finish their suspension. **(rule 14.3)**
*   For the duration of a temporary suspension, the offending team plays with one fewer player. **(rule 2.3)**
*   A player who has completed a temporary suspension is allowed to be substituted without first returning to the pitch. **(rule 2.3)**
*   Players re-entering the pitch for substitution purposes must do so within 3 meters of the center-line on their team's bench side, as agreed with the umpires. **(rule 2.3)**
*   Temporarily suspended players return to the pitch on the center-line. **(rule 2.3)**
*   The duration of a temporary suspension can be extended if a player misbehaves while already suspended. **(rule 14.4)**
*   Umpires should have a thorough understanding of the Rules of Indoor Hockey and use common sense in their interpretation. **(rule 1.4)**
*   Umpires are expected to deal with offenses promptly and firmly, applying the appropriate penalties. **(rule 1.4)**
*   Umpires should establish and maintain control throughout the match. **(rule 1.4)**
*   Umpires should utilize all available tools for control. **(rule 1.4)**
*   Umpires should apply the advantage rule to promote a flowing game, without losing control. **(rule 1.4)**
*   For any offense, a player can be cautioned, temporarily suspended for 1 minute (green card), temporarily suspended for a minimum of 2 minutes (yellow card), or permanently suspended (red card). **(rule 14.1)**
*   During any temporary suspension (green or yellow card), the offending team plays with one fewer player, whether the suspended player is on or off the pitch. **(rule 14.1)**
*   For a permanent suspension (red card), the offending team plays with one fewer player for the remainder of the match. **(rule 14.1)**
*   A personal penalty may be awarded in addition to another appropriate penalty. **(rule 14.1)**
*   From the award of a penalty corner until play restarts, no offending player can re-enter the pitch until play has resumed. **(rule 14.1)**
*   Permanently suspended players must leave the pitch and its surrounding area. **(rule 14.5)**
*   Field players leaving the pitch for reasons other than substitution (e.g., injury, refreshment, equipment change) can only re-enter within 3 meters of the center-line on the substitution side of the pitch. **(rule 2.4)**
*   Leaving and re-entering the pitch as part of play, such as a defender putting on a face mask during a penalty corner, can occur at any appropriate part of the pitch. **(rule 2.4)**
details.reasoning: The student's answer correctly identifies that a temporarily suspended player must remain in a designated place until the umpire allows them to resume play. The additional information provided, while not strictly required by the question, is accurate according to the provided rules and demonstrates a good understanding of the context.

details.question: In indoor field hockey, what is the maximum permissible weight of a stick, and what is the maximum length of the stick as measured from the top of the handle to the bottom of the head?
details.ground_truth: The maximum weight is 737 grams, and the maximum length is 105 cm.
details.bot_answer:
The maximum permissible weight for an indoor hockey stick is 737 grams, and its total length, from the top of the handle to the bottom of the head, cannot exceed 105 cm.

*   The total weight of the stick must not exceed 737 grams. **(page 63)**
*   The length of the stick, measured from the top of the handle to the bottom of the head, shall not be more than 105 cm. **(page 63)**
